title: Seeking Closeness
description: Learn how you express your need for connection.

questions.text: How do I show that I need more closeness?
choices: I become more attentive to you
I hint but don't always say

therapeutic.rationale: How we signal closeness needs reflects attachment communication patterns. Direct askers have secure communication; physical initiators use non-verbal bids; attention-givers hope for reciprocity; hinters learned indirect communication. Clear communication of closeness needs gets them met more reliably.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different closeness signaling means you may miss each other's bids. The direct asker may not notice the hinter's signals; the hinter may feel the direct asker doesn't need closeness. Learn to read your partner's language.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared closeness signaling means you'll recognize each other's needs. You speak the same attachment language.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How do you show your partner you need more closeness? Do they notice? What would help them understand your signals better?

questions.text: What from my past affects how I attach to you?

therapeutic.rationale: Our attachment history shapes current patterns. Relationship hurts create protective walls; family patterns become templates; abandonment creates hypervigilance; enforced independence creates self-reliance. Understanding your partner's history with compassion helps you not take their patterns personally.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different attachment histories mean different wounds informing current behavior. Your partner's walls or clinginess may come from experiences you didn't share. Approach their history with curiosity.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared attachment histories suggest similar formative experiences. You may deeply understand each other's patterns because you share similar origins.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What from your past shows up in how you attach to your partner? Have you shared this history with them? How does understanding the origin help?

questions.text: How comfortable am I asking for what I need?

therapeutic.rationale: Comfort expressing needs reflects attachment security and childhood experiences. Direct askers learned their needs were valid; flexible types adapt to context; hinters learned indirect routes were safer; holders-back fear rejection or burden. Secure attachment involves trusting that expressing needs won't damage the relationship.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different needs-expression comfort requires different invitation levels. The direct asker may need to explicitly invite the holder-back to share; the holder-back needs patience and safety.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared needs-expression comfort means you communicate similarly. If you both struggle, create explicit safety for needs-sharing.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How easy is it to ask your partner for what you need? Where did you learn your relationship with asking? What would make it easier?

questions.text: What triggers my anxiety in relationships?

therapeutic.rationale: Relationship anxiety triggers reveal attachment sensitivities. Unanswered-message anxiety suggests abandonment fears; mood-sensitivity suggests hypervigilance for rejection; ex-mentions suggest comparison anxiety; time-apart triggers suggest separation anxiety. Knowing your triggers helps you manage them.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different triggers mean different things activate each of your attachment systems. What seems trivial to one may be threatening to the other. Treat each other's triggers with care.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared triggers suggest similar attachment sensitivities. Be extra careful with your shared vulnerabilityâ€”you can both be activated at once.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What triggers relationship anxiety for you? Where does this sensitivity come from? Does your partner know what activates your worry?

questions.text: How do I feel about being vulnerable with you?
choices: I hold back to protect myself
It takes me time to open up

therapeutic.rationale: Vulnerability comfort is the gateway to deep connection. Safe-and-willing shows secure attachment; nervous-but-trying shows growth edge; holding-back shows self-protection; slow-opening shows cautious trust. True intimacy requires vulnerability from both partners.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different vulnerability comfort requires different pacing. The safe-and-willing may feel frustrated by the holder-back; the slow-opener may feel pressured. Respect each other's vulnerability pace.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared vulnerability comfort means you'll open at similar speeds. If you both hold back, intentionally create safety for deeper sharing.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How comfortable are you being truly vulnerable with your partner? What would help you open up more? What do you hold back?
